channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Shock Waves Hit the Global Economy, Posing Grave Risk to Europe
item.description: The threat to Europe’s industrial might and living standards is particularly acute as policymakers race to decouple the continent from Russia’s power sources.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Carsten Koall/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Brandenburg Gate in Berlin last Thursday, the first day a new German energy conservation law went into effect. Under the law, monuments may no longer be illuminated at night.

item.title: Garland Faces Tough Calls in Weighing Response to Trump Ruling
item.description: As the department decides whether to appeal the ruling on a special master, it is balancing a desire to speedily resolve the inquiry with the need to limit an expansive view of executive power.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Until the ruling, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland and his top officials had controlled the public narrative surrounding the inquiry.

item.title: F.B.I. Sought Interview With Trump Aide in Capitol Riot Case
item.description: Federal prosecutors issued a subpoena to William Russell, who served as a special assistant to the former president, and went to his home in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Justin Lane/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: William Russell, who served as a special assistant and the deputy director of advance under President Donald J. Trump, continued to work for him as a personal aide after he left office.

item.title: Ex-U.S. Attorney’s Book Addresses Pressure to Help Trump Causes
item.description: Geoffrey S. Berman, who headed the Manhattan office, says in a book the Justice Department pushed cases, against John Kerry and others, to help Mr. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s tweets set off pressure on prosecutors, according to the former top prosecutor’s book.

item.title: Bannon Surrenders to Face New York Indictment in Wall Case
item.description: Stephen K. Bannon, whom former President Donald J. Trump pardoned, has been entangled in what prosecutors have said was a crowdfunding fraud scheme.
item.dc:creator: Chelsia Rose Marcius
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: The charges against Stephen Bannon are believed to involve an effort to build a border wall.

item.title: Memphis Shooting Spree Leaves 4 Dead
item.description: The police arrested a 19-year-old who they said had carried out a string of shootings. Residents had been urged to stay indoors during the search.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:credit: Houston Cofield for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police in Memphis flooded the city on Wednesday in pursuit of a gunman who killed four people.

item.title: 2022 NFL Season Preview: What to Expect From Every Team
item.description: The Broncos bet big on Russell Wilson, the Packers went all in on defense and Tom Brady endures. But did any N.F.L. team position itself to ascend higher than the Los Angeles Rams this season?
item.dc:creator: Ken Belson, Joe Drape, Jesus Jiménez, Emmanuel Morgan, Kris Rhim and Jenny Vrentas

item.title: In Ukraine, a Beekeeper Hunkers Down With His ‘Frontline Bees’
item.description: With nearby sunflower fields unplanted and rockets overhead, a Ukrainian’s bees ventured toward the battlefront and returned with a bumper crop.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Even as the war encroached, Petro Fedorovych, a beekeeper, stayed in his small village of Bohdanivka. “I built this house with my hands,” he said. “I will never leave.”

item.title: Why a Narrow, Hard-Right Republican House Majority Could Spell Chaos
item.description: Kevin McCarthy, who would become speaker if Republicans retake the chamber, could face a series of headaches. But beyond him, the nation might struggle to avoid a damaging default on its debt.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: If Representative Kevin McCarthy, left, becomes speaker of the House, he will have to manage a Republican caucus that has shifted ever further to the right.

item.title: How to Save a Forest by Burning It
item.description: Prescribed burns are key to reducing the risk of catastrophic wildfires. Scientists are using high-tech tools to ensure they can be done safely in a warming world.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Andri Tambunan
item.media:credit: Andri Tambunan for The New York Times

item.title: Climate Change Could Worsen Supply Chain Turmoil
item.description: A drought that has crippled economic activity in southwestern China hints at the kind of disruption that climate change could wreak on global supply chains.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: A drought in China has had ripple effects for businesses around the globe.

item.title: Alcaraz Beats Sinner in Late, Late U.S. Open Match
item.description: The Spanish teenager needed five sets and more than five hours to reach the semifinals in a match that ended shortly before 3 a.m. in New York.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Carlos Alcaraz on Thursday after his victory over Jannik Sinner in a quarterfinal match at the U.S. Open.

item.title: When Weird Al Yankovic Met Daniel Radcliffe, Things Got … Well, You Know
item.description: For their decidedly nonfactual rock biopic, the pop-music parodist and the “Harry Potter” star found themselves on the same wavelength.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m amazed the lawyers let us get away with this movie, frankly,” Yankovic said.

item.title: The New Wave of Tasting Menus Is Affordable and Approachable
item.description: With lower price points and less attitude, chefs around the country are finding fun and freedom in the once-stuffy form.
item.dc:creator: Brett Anderson
item.category: Mosquito Supper Club (New Orleans, La, Restaurant)
Her Place Supper Club (Philadelphia, Pa, Restaurant)
item.media:credit: Neal Santos for The New York Times

item.title: Who Will Control the Senate? The Answer Could Be in an Email.
item.description: Do you think your newfound popularity has something to do with politics?
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins
item.media:credit: Mariam Zuhaib/Associated Press

item.title: Your Childhood Home Is in Front of You. Do You Go In?
item.description: A childhood home may hold a nearly undimmed set of early memories, as if its walls formed a time capsule we sealed behind us as we left.
item.dc:creator: Mark Vanhoenacker
item.media:credit: Marine Buffard

item.title: The Man Who Won the Republican Party Before Trump Did
item.description: Pat Buchanan knew that “the greatest vacuum in American politics is to the right of Ronald Reagan.”
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hemmer
item.media:credit: Eric Draper/Associated Press
item.media:description: Pat Buchanan campaigns with a Winchester rifle in 1996.

item.title: Pakistan’s Vulnerability to Disaster Was Through the Roof. Then Came the Floods.
item.description: The Pakistani climate scientist Fahad Saeed on why he’s scared.
item.dc:creator: David Wallace-Wells
item.media:credit: Ibrahim Rayintakath

item.title: What Antarctica’s Disintegration Asks of Us
item.description: What if we saw Antarctica as a harbinger of transformation rather than doom?
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Rush
item.media:credit: Photographs by Elizabeth Rush
item.media:description: Icebergs in the Southern Ocean.

item.title: This Is the Kind of Storytelling That Economics Needs
item.description: Science fiction opens the mind to other ways the world could be.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; image by CSA Images via Getty

item.title: What Mass Shooters Often Have in Common
item.description: Readers discuss the warning signs that can predict a mass shooting. Also: Self-publishing; calls for secession; floods and droughts.
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many experts who study how to prevent mass shootings have come to focus on marked changes in behavior, demeanor or appearance, uncharacteristic fights or arguments, or telling others of plans for violence.

item.title: Covid’s Toll on Native Americans
item.description: Covid’s death toll in Indigenous communities has no modern precedent.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez and Ashley Wu

item.title: Is California Jump-Starting the Electric Vehicle Revolution?
item.description: A new rule aiming to reduce emissions could set off a major shift in the automobile industry.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, Michael Simon Johnson, Will Reid, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Paige Cowett, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Interstate 10 in California. On the way to its ultimate goal, the state will require that 35 percent of new passenger vehicles sold by 2026 — and 68 percent by 2030 — produce no carbon emissions.

item.title: 4 Types of Voters We’re Watching in the Midterms
item.description: For our podcast The Run-Up, Astead Herndon and his team are talking with voters of all stripes. For many of them, frustration with politics is tied to their worries about democracy.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Midterm elections are typically a judgment of the president or party in power, but this year’s political landscape could be different.

item.title: We Want to Hear About Your Experience With Egg Freezing
item.description: The Times is looking for stories from readers.
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times

item.title: Myles Sanderson, Suspect in Canada Stabbings, Is Dead
item.description: After a four-day manhunt, the police arrested Myles Sanderson, a suspect in a stabbing rampage that left 10 dead in the Canadian province. He was pronounced dead at a hospital after going into “medical distress,” the police said.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen, Vjosa Isai and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Lars Hagberg/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police took Myles Sanderson, who had been driving the white pickup truck, into custody Wednesday afternoon in Saskatchewan.

item.title: Iraq’s Instability Deepens Amid Political Paralysis and Clashes
item.description: Politicians have failed to form a new government nearly a year after the last elections. Baghdad just saw its worst militia clashes in years. And despite vast oil wealth, the state can’t provide basic services.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Emily Garthwaite
item.media:description: The Central Bank of Iraq, designed by the renowned Iraqi-born architect Zaha Hadid, under construction on the banks of the Tigris River in Baghdad.

item.title: NYC Schools Reopen With Focus on Recovery From Pandemic Losses
item.description: “We need to show them: We’re back,” said the head of the principals’ union as children return to school Thursday with Covid restrictions largely ended.
item.dc:creator: Lola Fadulu and Troy Closson
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: Public schools open in New York City on Thursday, the start of a crucial year for recouping pandemic learning loss.

item.title: When Teens Find Misinformation, These Teachers Are Ready
item.description: Media literacy efforts are intensifying, targeting students as they approach voting age. But some educators struggle “to push through that apathy.”
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul Blakesley has spent years teaching high school students in Colorado how to identify bias and misinformation.

item.title: Are Vasectomies Reversible?
item.description: If you are considering the procedure, but are worried about its permanence, here is what experts want you to know.
item.dc:creator: Jen A. Miller
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: Why Is My Eyelid Twitching? Questions and Answers
item.description: And how do I get it to stop?
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Mark Elzey for The New York Times

item.title: What Should I Look for When Buying Whole Grains?
item.description: There are several reliable ways to identify whole-grain foods.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Egan
item.media:credit: iStock

item.title: Is the Saturated Fat in Chocolate as Bad as the Fat in Meat?
item.description: Chocolate contains a healthier blend of fats than meats do. But don’t go overboard.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Ryan Liebe for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: Are Calcium Supplements Safe?
item.description: Kidney stones are a known risk, but studies have investigated other potential safety concerns, including an increased risk of death, cancer and heart disease.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: In the Hamptons, the Rich Got Their Labor Day. The Workers Kept Working.
item.description: Tumbleweed Tuesday, the unofficial holiday for the tourism industry in Long Island’s East End, is in jeopardy.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Calissa, a restaurant in Water Mill, New York, threw a barbecue party for its workers in honor of Tumbleweed Tuesday.
